banner.mainContentHeadline: The podcast where science meets business
banner.mainContent: From fixing meetings to finding a mentor, get new insights to help you enjoy your time at work and thrive in your career.

videoData.title: How to talk (and listen) to transgender people
videoData.socialTitle: How to talk (and listen) to transgender people

recommendations.blurb: Check out these resources, curated by Jackson Bird

recItems.headline: *Gender Outlaws: The Next Generation*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK
recItems.note:
Kate Bornstein and S. Bear Bergman
Seal Press, 2010

recItems.blurb: A support guide for friends and family
recItems.headline: PFLAG’s Our Trans Loved Ones
recItems.label: EXPLORE

recItems.blurb: A toolkit from the Harry Potter Alliance on making the world a safer place for transgender individuals, featuring actions to take on individual, community and policy levels.
recItems.headline: Protego
recItems.label: EXPLORE

recItems.blurb: A visual breakdown of the differences between gender identity, gender expression, sex assignment and sexual/romantic attraction.
recItems.headline: The Genderbread Person
recItems.label: EXPLORE

recItems.blurb: Jackson Bird’s podcast amplifying the stories of transgender people of today.
recItems.headline: *Transmission*
recItems.label: LISTEN

recItems.headline: *One From The Vaults*
recItems.label: LISTEN

recItems.label: WATCH

recItems.headline: A playlist from Jackson Bird on gender
recItems.label: WATCH

recItems.blurb: A quick, witty video on how gender expression does not define us.
recItems.headline: "Watermelon..."
recItems.label: WATCH

recItems.blurb: A brief and beautiful history of the modern transgender movement.
recItems.headline: *Time Marches Forward and So Do We*
recItems.label: WATCH

recItems.blurb: Writer and performer Jacob Tobia shuts down transgender myths and assumptions on Dylan Marron’s Shutting Down Bullsh*t series.
recItems.headline: "Gender Myths: Shutting Down BS with Jacob Tobia"
recItems.label: WATCH

recItems.blurb: Buzzfeed flips the script on comments transgender people hear all too frequently.
recItems.headline: "If Trans People Said The Stuff Cisgender People Say"
recItems.label: WATCH

recItems.headline: Breaking the Silence Around Gender Dysphoria
recItems.label: WATCH

recItems.headline: "Transgender 101: A Guide to Gender and Identity to Help You Keep Up with the Conversation"
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE

recItems.headline: "Is it ok to out someone as transgender if they’re not around?"
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE

recItems.blurb: This series features profiles of dozens of transgender individuals from diverse backgrounds and experiences.
recItems.headline: Transgender Lives: Your Stories
recItems.label: EXPLORE

recItems.blurb: If you think you might be transgender, I recommend reading this article by Adrian Ballou with what they wish they had known. It also includes links to over fifty resources for trans and questioning individuals.
recItems.headline: I Think I Might Be Trans: 8 Important Notes On Questioning and 50+ Resources to Get You Started
recItems.label: EXPLORE

takeAction.blurb: **Learn more** about transgender experiences by listening to *Transmission*.

nodes.whoTheyAre: TED Resident Jackson Bird is using digital storytelling to demystify the transgender experience.
nodes.whyListen:
After publicly coming out as transgender in 2015, Jackson Bird has been committed to amplifying the voices of transgender people and breaking down the stigma attached to their experiences. He shares the stories of fellow transgender people on his podcast, Transmission, as well as on his ongoing YouTube series, "Queerstory."

Bird is also known for his work with the Harry Potter Alliance (HPA), a nonprofit that activates online fan communities towards social action. A 2017 TED Resident and 2016 YouTube NextUp Creator, Bird was also a 2015 LogoTV Social Trailblazer nominee and hailed by MTV as a "Social Media Warrior Who Helped Restore Our Faith in 2016."  

Jackson is currently a Craig Newmark Organizer-In-Residence at Civic Hall and runs the monthly LGBTQIA+ Creators Group at YouTube Space NY. He currently lives in New York City.

videoData.description: Gender should be the least remarkable thing about someone, but transgender people are still too often misunderstood. To help those who are scared to ask questions or nervous about saying the wrong thing, Jackson Bird shares a few ways to think about trans issues. And in this funny, frank talk, he clears up a few misconceptions about pronouns, transitioning, bathrooms and more.
videoData.socialDescription: Gender should be the least remarkable thing about someone, but transgender people are still too often misunderstood. To help those who are scared to ask questions or nervous about saying the wrong thing, Jackson Bird shares a few ways to think about trans issues. And in this funny, frank talk, he clears up a few misconceptions about pronouns, transitioning, bathrooms and more.

cues.text: Hi, I'm Jack,
and I'm transgender.
Let me take a guess at some of thoughts

that might be running
through your head right now.
"Transgender?

Wait, does that mean that they're
actually a man or actually a woman?"
"I wonder if he's had the surgery yet ...
Oh, now I'm looking at his crotch.

Look to the right,
that's a safe place to look."

"Yes, I knew it!
No real man has hips like those."
"My friend's daughter is transgender --
I wonder if they know each other."
"Oh my gosh, he is so brave.

I would totally support his right
to use the men's bathroom.
Wait, but how does he use the bathroom?
How does he have sex?"

OK, OK, let's stop
those hypothetical questions
before we get too close for my comfort.
I mean, don't get me wrong,

I did come here today to share
my personal experiences being transgender,

but I did not wake up this morning
wanting to tell an entire audience
about my sex life.

Of course, that's the problem
with being trans, right?

People are pretty much always
wondering how we have sex

and what kind of equipment
we're working with below the belt.
Being trans is awkward.

And not just because the gender
I was assigned at birth
mismatches the one I really am.
Being trans is awkward

because everyone else gets awkward
when they're around me.

People who support me and all other
trans people wholeheartedly
are often so scared to say to wrong thing,

so embarrassed to not know
what they think they should,
that they never ask.

Part of what was so nerve-racking
about coming out as transgender

was knowing that people
wouldn't know what I meant.
And when someone comes out as gay,
people know what that means,
but when you come out as trans,
you have to face the misconceptions

that will color other people's
impressions of you
even after you've educated them ...
And you will have to educate them.
When I came out,
I wrote at 10-page encyclopedic document

with a zip-file attachment
of music and videos

that I sent to every
single person I came out to.
(Laughter)

And I kept it in my email signature
for months afterwards,

because you also
don't ever stop coming out.

I came out to the accountant
helping me with my taxes

and the TSA agents who didn't know
which one of them should pat me down,
the man or the woman.

I mean, I just came out
to everyone watching this.
When I came out to my dad,

to my great relief, he was totally cool
with me being trans,

but as soon as I started talking
about physically transitioning,
he freaked.

And I quickly realized it was because he,
like so many other people,

think that physical transition
means just one thing:
the surgery.
Now, listen,
if there were one magical surgery
that could turn me into a tall, muscular,

societally perfect image
of a man overnight,
I'd sign up in a heartbeat.
Unfortunately, it isn't that simple.

There are dozens of different
gender-affirming surgeries
from chest surgeries to bottom surgeries
to facial feminization and man-sculpting.

Many trans people will only ever undergo
one procedure in their lifetime, if that.

Maybe because they don't
personally feel the need
but also because they're expensive,

and health insurance
is only beginning to cover them.

Instead, the first step for a trans person
seeking physical transition
is usually hormone replacement therapy.

Hormones are why I have a deeper voice
and some sparse whiskers on my neck
and a giant pimple on my chin.

Basically, they put you
through a second puberty ...
it's a blast.
(Laughter)

Now, because our transitions
are slower and steadier

than historic misconceptions
can lead people to believe,
there can be some confusion

about when to call someone
by their new name and pronouns.

There's no distinct point
in physical transition

at which a trans person
becomes their true gender.

As soon as they tell you
their new name and pronouns,
that's when you start using them.
It can be difficult to make the change.
You might slip up here and there;

I've slipped up myself
with other trans people.
But I always think to myself,

if we can change from calling
Puff Daddy to P. Diddy,

and if we apologize profusely
when we've used the wrong gender pronoun
for someone's pet cat --

I mean, I think we can make
the same effort
for the real humans in our lives.

Now, there is no topic that makes other
people more awkward about trans people
than public bathrooms.
Ah, the bathrooms --

the latest political flash point
for LGBT opponents.
Here's a fun fact about bathrooms:

more US congressmen have been convicted
of assaulting someone in a public bathroom
than trans people have been.
(Laughter)

The truth is we trans people are so much
more scared of you than you are of us.

It's a huge point of discussion
in trans communities

about which bathroom
to start using and when,

so we don't attract attention
that could lead to violence against us.
I personally started using the men's room

when I started getting confused
and frightened looks in the women's room,

even though I was petrified
to start going into the men's room.

And often we opt to just
not go to the bathroom at all.
A 2015 national survey of trans people

found that eight percent of us
had had a urinary tract infection
in the past year
as a result of avoiding restrooms.

These bathroom bills
aren't protecting anyone.
All they're doing

is ensuring that when trans people
are assaulted in bathrooms,

the law will no longer be on our side
when we report it.

Being trans means a daily onslaught
of these misconceptions.
And I have it pretty easy.
I am a white, able-bodied guy

sitting nearly at the peak
of privilege mountain.
For non-binary people,
for trans women,
for trans people of color,
it is so much harder.

So I've given you a starter pack
of trans knowledge

that I hope will lead
to more learning on your own.
Talk to trans people.
Listen to us.
Amplify our voices.

Take the heat off of us
and educate those around you
so we don't have to every time.
Maybe someday, when I say,
"Hi, I'm Jack, and I'm transgender,"
the only response I'll get is,
"Hi, nice to meet you."
Thank you.
(Applause)

footnotes.annotation:
> There are dozens of different gender-affirming surgeries from chest surgeries to bottom surgeries to facial feminization and man-sculpting.

[An outline of the most common gender confirming procedures](https://www.plasticsurgery.org/reconstructive-procedures/gender-confirmation-surgeries) from the American Society of Plastic Surgeons

["16 Myths About Gender Confirmation Surgery"](https://everydayfeminism.com/2014/10/gender-confirmation-surgery/) by Brynn Tannehill, *Everyday Feminism*

[An excellent resource for nonbinary individuals considering physical transition](https://genderqueer.me/2014/03/06/5-myths-about-genderqueer-transition/) from Micah at genderqueer.me

> Maybe because they don't personally feel the need, but also because they're expensive, and health insurance is only beginning to cover them.

A succinct explanation, with several additional resources, about [why not all transgender people medically transition](https://www.vox.com/cards/transgender-myths-fiction-facts/myth-4-all-trans-people-medically-transition) from Vox.

["Here's What Trans People Who Aren't Medically Transitioning Want You To Know,"](https://www.buzzfeed.com/skarlan/still-valid?utm_term=.fplA3y7Px6#.smWv9KXzYQ) a quick read from BuzzFeed

From lack of insurance coverage to discriminatory gatekeeping and having to educate providers on our bodies, transgender people face infinite hurdles in accessing healthcare (whether transition-related or not). For more on these issues, visit [GLAAD’s transgender healthcare resource portal](https://www.glaad.org/healthcare) and the [National Center for Transgender Equality’s comprehensive outline of transgender rights and resources relating to health care](https://www.transequality.org/know-your-rights/healthcare).

> Instead, the first step for a trans person seeking physical transition is usually hormone replacement therapy.

[An overview of hormone replacement therapy for both transmasculine and transfeminine individuals](http://www.revelandriot.com/resources/trans-health/) from Revel & Riot.

["7 Things You Should Know If You’re Considering Hormones For Your Transition"](https://www.teenvogue.com/story/what-is-hormone-replacement-therapy) by Vera Papisova from Teen Vogue. This article also includes a ton of helpful links and resources.

[A look at how five years of testosterone treatment, social transition, and other gender confirmation procedures affected one young man](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HY0Yz5Hce8U&index=2&list=PL1g3MXAZto6JCfsVdWEr14J8Sz_0qiDUK) from Skylar Kergil.

> As soon as they tell you their new name and pronouns, that's when you start using them.

[Tips for allies](https://www.glaad.org/transgender/allies) from GLAAD

["Why Pronouns Matter for Trans People,"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N_yBGQqg7kM&index=1&list=PL1g3MXAZto6JCfsVdWEr14J8Sz_0qiDUK) a video from Buzzfeed

["All About Pronouns,"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4NcMV5dsmgI) a video from Ash Hardell

Trans ally and CEO of Everyone Is Gay, Kristin Russo, [talks authentically about the challenges of changing someone’s pronouns and using gender-neutral pronouns.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kvsr87Ig8Ao&index=2&list=WL).

[“How to React After Accidentally Misgendering Someone”](http://www.pdxqcenter.org/how-to-react-after-accidentally-misgendering-someone/) from Q Center

> There is no topic that makes other people more awkward about trans people than public bathrooms.

Learn more about bathroom bills from [GLAAD’s Debunking the Bathroom Bill Myth](http://www.glaad.org/sites/default/files/Debunking_the_Bathroom_Bill_Myth_2017.pdf).

Watch [Kat Blaque’s](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GuxkpPqZ8PE&t=183s&list=WL&index=11) powerful educational video meets spoken word poem about transgender people and bathrooms.

I was fortunate enough to appear on the pilot episode of the Gotham Award-Nominated Series from Dylan Marron and SeriouslyTV, [Sitting in Bathrooms with Trans People](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZYvej-OWgJE&list=PLPGwHnW-HgFm-wJ93QnUbX6Cle_gmOuax&index=6). The light-hearted series does a fantastic job of portraying trans people as ordinary people who just want to pee.

> More US congressmen have been convicted of assaulting someone in a public bathroom than trans people have been.

[Media Matters did an in-depth report](https://www.mediamatters.org/blog/2014/03/20/debunking-the-big-myth-about-transgender-inclus/198530) on popular accusations of transgender people assaulting people in bathrooms, debunking many popular stories about false incidents.

While it’s possible a transgender person may have been convicted for assaulting someone in a bathroom by the time you watch this, there [remain a number of United States congressmen who have already been convicted of just that.](https://www.mediamatters.org/blog/2014/03/20/debunking-the-big-myth-about-transgender-inclus/198530)

It’s important to note that states and municipalities with protections for transgender people in bathrooms have never seen "a rise in sexual violence or other public safety issues due to nondiscrimination laws," [according to a coalition of sexual assault and domestic violence groups](https://www.lambdalegal.org/blog/20160421_sadv) who formed in opposition to mounting discriminatory bathroom legislation in 2016. Indeed, transgender people are more often the ones in danger in public spaces, like bathrooms, with [64% of us experiencing sexual assault at some point in our lifetimes.](http://www.transequality.org/sites/default/files/docs/usts/USTS%20Full%20Report%20-%20FINAL%201.6.17.pdf)

> A 2015 national survey of trans people found that eight percent of us had had a urinary tract infection in the past year.

This statistic comes from the National Center for Transgender Equality’s most recent [U.S. Transgender Survey](http://www.transequality.org/sites/default/files/docs/usts/USTS%20Full%20Report%20-%20FINAL%201.6.17.pdf).

> For non-binary people, for trans women, for trans people of color, it is so much harder.

[Explaining nonbinary genders in a historical and scientific context](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nlc8H4WUqEs&index=57&list=PL1g3MXAZto6JCfsVdWEr14J8Sz_0qiDUK) from Riley J. Dennis.

[An interview with Cecilia Gentili](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eAsRkOKoyjc&index=2&list=PL1g3MXAZto6Lgw2DHk32U3rGTHWiGZC_b), an activist and trans woman of color.

[TED Speaker Tiq Milan](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ev_HmE_pJEM) discusses the intersection of race and gender identity as a black trans man.

The New York Times’ [Transgender Lives: Your Stories](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/projects/storywall/transgender-today) series, which features profiles of dozens of transgender individuals from diverse backgrounds and experiences.

Trans women of color are the most at risk of being the victim of violent crimes. Here’s [a list of the women we’ve lost to violent crimes so far in 2017.](https://www.hrc.org/resources/violence-against-the-transgender-community-in-2017) You can honor their memory on [Transgender Day of Remembrance](https://www.glaad.org/tdor) in November of every year.
